EDITORIAL COMMENT
A WELCOME INNOVATION
RADITION concerning college year books is very emphatic regarding one point. Every 'university annual must have some
one theme which motivates its art work and general make-up. bowing
to this universal custom, the editors of the 1927 Hullabaloo employed the life career of a knight in armor as the central theme of
the illustrations which introduced the various classes. The freshmen were represented as young warriors about to serve their apprenticeships. An •illustration of a sheep herder tending his flocks
introduced the sophomores. A sketch of a warrior paying homage
to his lady was the froutpiece for the junior's section, while the
seniors were symbolized by a knight in the act of slaying a dragon.
This year, the Hullabaloo staff will,attempt an innovation: Instead of adopting some theme, fcireigli' to the University, they have
decided to use, as their motivating idea, the life of Sidney Lanierr
Lamer, contrary to the popular notion of many students, was.a man of action. He was not the conventional .poet---the-half human,
eccentric individual who ekes out a bare existence in some actic.
He was not the Bohemian type -which lives solely for the life philosophy of "art for art's 'sake." Lanier led an active,- diverse life.
He fought with Robert E. Lee in the Civil War and endured the
hardships of the prison camp. He was an accomplished musician,
•
an ardent student and an enthusiastic teacher.
Even though his body' was wracked with the ravagd of disease,
Sidney Lamer continued on, doggedly, persistently, fighting the good.
fight. HiS beautiful lyrics reflect in no way the utter hopelessness
and despair which followed him to his grave.
Unfottunately, however, we feel that Lanier's work and the prominent place which he holds in American literature is not properly '
appreciated by the University undergraduate of today. Once a year,
an assembly is held to honot the memory of the great poet and the
rambling ivy on Gilmao Hall's walls commemorates the deeds of this
famed alumnus. But, in spite of these attempts to keep the memory
of Lanier alive, we fear that the real significance of his work has
not-been made sufficiently impressive.
Perhaps some day the University will see fit to establish a regular.
undergraduate course for the study of Lanier's life and writings.
Certainly, such a course would be the most appropriate of all memorials.
• •
In adopting Lanier's life for its art theme, the 1929 Hullabaloo
staff is rendering a real service.. It will show the poet in the true
light of his accomplishments. He will be revealed as a soldier, a
teacher and a musician, as well as a poet. And, above all, it will
show Lanier as a'man of courage, a man of valor and a man of
action.

ONE MORE DON'T
VERY year the freshman class is subjected to an excruciating.
torture. Well-meaning upper classmen, ever-watchful and interested in the
-.4fare, pour a' stI4.4 flood of advice into
his ears. He is told what courses to take, what fraternity to "go,"
what activities to try out forts,.....r.or4140first two weeks of his college life; he hears the same incessant din. Do this and do that;
don't do this and don't do that. Sometimes we wonder how the
average freshman is able to stand the mental strain.
The first year men are gradually becoming more worldly-wise and
sophisticated and, as they approach this state of perfect bliss, they ,
are paying less and less attention to the expert opinions of the upper
classmen. But before the frosh become too blase, we have just one
word of advice to add to the sum total of suggestions.
Don't try to be a big man on the campus. Don't try to make
every student activity on the theory that some day you may become
an 0. D. K. Pick out one or two of them and make an earnest attempt to succeed in your work.
Student activities,' taken in moderation, afford practical experience
which no college course offers; but if indulged in to excess, they
become a real menace to efficient scholastic work. Make publication,
work or dramatics your avocation, not your vocation. College, after
all, is a place for study.

There is a custom in this University, however, to hold an annual
riot, affray, and disturbance of the
peace known a trifle inaccurately as
a Banquet Season. At this festive
period it is the practice of the sophomores to capture or to attempt to
capture the frosh 'officers, and for
the frosh to annoy the sophomore

EDITORIAL COMMENT
A WELCOME INNOVATION
RADITION concerning college year books is very emphatic regarding one point. Every 'university annual must have some
one theme which motivates its art work and general make-up. bowing
to this universal custom, the editors of the 1927 Hullabaloo employed the life career of a knight in armor as the central theme of
the illustrations which introduced the various classes. The freshmen were represented as young warriors about to serve their apprenticeships. An •illustration of a sheep herder tending his flocks
introduced the sophomores. A sketch of a warrior paying homage
to his lady was the froutpiece for the junior's section, while the
seniors were symbolized by a knight in the act of slaying a dragon.
This year, the Hullabaloo staff will,attempt an innovation: Instead of adopting some theme, fcireigli' to the University, they have
decided to use, as their motivating idea, the life of Sidney Lanierr
Lamer, contrary to the popular notion of many students, was.a man of action. He was not the conventional .poet---the-half human,
eccentric individual who ekes out a bare existence in some actic.
He was not the Bohemian type -which lives solely for the life philosophy of "art for art's 'sake." Lanier led an active,- diverse life.
He fought with Robert E. Lee in the Civil War and endured the
hardships of the prison camp. He was an accomplished musician,
•
an ardent student and an enthusiastic teacher.
Even though his body' was wracked with the ravagd of disease,
Sidney Lamer continued on, doggedly, persistently, fighting the good.
fight. HiS beautiful lyrics reflect in no way the utter hopelessness
and despair which followed him to his grave.
Unfottunately, however, we feel that Lanier's work and the prominent place which he holds in American literature is not properly '
appreciated by the University undergraduate of today. Once a year,
an assembly is held to honot the memory of the great poet and the
rambling ivy on Gilmao Hall's walls commemorates the deeds of this
famed alumnus. But, in spite of these attempts to keep the memory
of Lanier alive, we fear that the real significance of his work has
not-been made sufficiently impressive.
Perhaps some day the University will see fit to establish a regular.
undergraduate course for the study of Lanier's life and writings.
Certainly, such a course would be the most appropriate of all memorials.
• •
In adopting Lanier's life for its art theme, the 1929 Hullabaloo
staff is rendering a real service.. It will show the poet in the true
light of his accomplishments. He will be revealed as a soldier, a
teacher and a musician, as well as a poet. And, above all, it will
show Lanier as a'man of courage, a man of valor and a man of
action.

ONE MORE DON'T
VERY year the freshman class is subjected to an excruciating.
torture. Well-meaning upper classmen, ever-watchful and interested in the
-.4fare, pour a' stI4.4 flood of advice into
his ears. He is told what courses to take, what fraternity to "go,"
what activities to try out forts,.....r.or4140first two weeks of his college life; he hears the same incessant din. Do this and do that;
don't do this and don't do that. Sometimes we wonder how the
average freshman is able to stand the mental strain.
The first year men are gradually becoming more worldly-wise and
sophisticated and, as they approach this state of perfect bliss, they ,
are paying less and less attention to the expert opinions of the upper
classmen. But before the frosh become too blase, we have just one
word of advice to add to the sum total of suggestions.
Don't try to be a big man on the campus. Don't try to make
every student activity on the theory that some day you may become
an 0. D. K. Pick out one or two of them and make an earnest attempt to succeed in your work.
Student activities,' taken in moderation, afford practical experience
which no college course offers; but if indulged in to excess, they
become a real menace to efficient scholastic work. Make publication,
work or dramatics your avocation, not your vocation. College, after
all, is a place for study.

There is a custom in this University, however, to hold an annual
riot, affray, and disturbance of the
peace known a trifle inaccurately as
a Banquet Season. At this festive
period it is the practice of the sophomores to capture or to attempt to
capture the frosh 'officers, and for
the frosh to annoy the sophomore
